i can see you've worked hard on it, but israel would never cede the entire unannexed west bank. the most generous proposals they made to the palestinians, back in the day (1990s) still allowed them to keep the largest settlements in the west bank. nobody, least of all israel, wants to import the population of gaza, or part of that population. even egypt is terrified of the gazans, and other arab states are also less-than-enamored of them. i don't think israel's population would ever accept a population inflow like that. what you're describing is a type of right of return, and israel doesn't have much interest in that. i also think the palestinians on the west bank would be loathe to approve an agreement that rewards the gazans, but not them. in other words, what you're describing is an agreement by which gazans can potentially live in israel (and thereby attempt to reclaim their lost property there), while the west bank population would not have a similar right. given the divide between gaza and the west bank politically, i doubt the former would agree to this. i may be wrong though -- who knows? you're trying to achieve a balance of taking-and-giving to make things fair--however, for both sides, most of what you're describing crosses important red lines that are unacceptable to each party. this, of course, is why the conflict persists. there's no real middle ground in this conflict. the israelis don't want to give up land. the palestinians won't give up their land claims or their right of return. also -- i'm not jewish or israeli -- but i know for a fact the israelis will never accept a return to a divided jerusalem. partial withdrawal from the west bank is imaginable. that could happen -- it's not impossible. it's been part of previous peace proposals. but i think jerusalem is off the table for them.

you have quite a one-sided view of the conflict and seem to have accepted only the zionist framing. >correct my statements if they are wrong as i am still learning about the war. from what i know, britain promised the region to the jews and the arabs at the same time, of course this will start a war kinda? britain committed itself to establish a jewish national home in palestine in 1917 with the balfour declaration. they also separately promised to support an independent arab state in exchange for arab support in defeating the ottoman empire. you could say that they are incompatible commitments, and in a way they are, but the important part is the actions that followed. after 1917 britain worked with the zionist settlers to create quasi-state infrastructure in palestine for the zionists and brutally suppressed the palestinian opposition. so you can say they followed through on their commitment made in the balfour declaration. on the other hand, they did not follow through on their commitment to an independent arab state. they secretly agreed with france how the region should be split between them in the sykes picot agreement. >how would that be israel‚Äôs fault for coming back to their ancestral homeland when the owner of the land tells you that you can have it? well first because britain wasn't the 'owner of the land', it was a colonial power. and more importantly because there were already people living there. settlers coming to a place and demanding the natives leave so they can establish a state is still wrong whether or not the settlers view it as their ancestral homeland. >despite this israel tries to have a 2 state solution 4 different times. palestine denies it every time and starts wars with israel. israel wins every time and palestine loses land because of it. again i ask, how does that make israel the bad guy? i'm not sure what the 4 times you are referring to, but this is at best a very one sided way of presenting the history. after 1948, you have 750,000 palestinians who have been ethnically cleansed from their homes who are now stateless. since then, israel has prevented them from returning to their homes, and at the same time blocked any moves towards an independent, sovereign and viable palestinian state. in 1967, israel invaded and occupied more territory, including the west bank and east jerusalem, the latter of which is the centre of palestinian economic, religious and cultural life. it also fragmented the west bank into separate areas cut off from each other and surrounded by new israeli settlements, and cuts off gaza from the rest of palestine and the rest of the world more generally. so the primary opposition to israel these days tends to focus on the genocide in gaza (obviously), and the occupation and oppression of palestinians in the west bank and east jerusalem. >in 2005 they give palestine gaza and what happens? hamas uses it to build miles of tunnels and send hundreds or thousands of missiles to israel.¬† this is a common misconception. israel withdrew its settlers and soldiers from gaza in 2005, but it didn't give palestine gaza. it was still in effective control, so was still the occupying power according to international law and the leading international bodies. the leading expert on the political economy of gaza is sara roy of harvard, and her work showing how israel deliberately 'de-developed' gaza's economy during this period is required reading on this topic. >what would you have done if you were israel? the obvious answer is not commit a genocide, but i will expand on that a little. the key point is to understand the underlying cause and work to address it. palestinian resistance has come in many forms, but at its heart its a fight against an occupying power who has expelled them from their homeland and rendered them a stateless people at the mercy of israeli occupation and aggression. the solution is to take the difficult steps necessary to end the occupation and work towards living in peace. end the siege on gaza and the illegal settlement expansion in the west bank, and give equal rights and freedoms to palestinians as israeli jews currently enjoy. it's a difficult process and it wouldn't solve everything overnight. but the current playbook is also untenable. it just reproduces a cycle of violence that will end with the extermination or expulsion of one group of people. we desperately need a new approach and new ideas, and that will take bravery and real leaders, not just politicians.

well, for one thing, they're not necessarily having that many babies if we take a long view. it's true, they're still pumping 'em out far above the international average, but we must remember that this average is falling both the world over and of course within palestinian society within and outside the territories. for palestinians within israel and the territories the fertility rate used to be around 9, which was an eye-watering number. the immediate diaspora was probably similar, given their rate of growth. still, it's down to either half that or in some cases approaching a more a western rate, depending on where you look and who you look at. now, we don't really have the data necessary to make an accurate assessment of how the present stage of the conflict will affect fertility rates either now (reported births are reportedly down 41%, but recorded births is the operative phrase here) or within the next few years. however, we can make some ballpark speculation and assume it'll probably go up. access to healthcare was a big reason for the global drop in fertility over the 20th century, since it upended one of the main reasons for pumping out kids, which was general childhood mortality. well, the healthcare system is in ruins and will probably remain so for at least a few years. and the natural human response to increased childhood mortality, as we've seen the world over, is really just keep on pumpin' . y'know, roll the dice, if you make more well then at least a couple of em might make it to adulthood. that'll probably lead to a brief explosion in fertility if healthcare is rebuilt rapidly, as was the case with the 20th century expansion of healthcare infrastructure, which should of course occur for moral reasons but even so one must acknowledge what can also occur alongside.

>did indonesians start calling themselves indonesian in 1949 just to undermine someone elses claim to the land? yes, that's essentially correct. the concept of indonesian was a project started by an anti-colonialist political party, sarekat islam, who in 1912, promoted the idea that 'indonesian' was any person living under dutch colonial rule in the dutch east indies (they were initially founded to oppose chinese traders, but within a year pivoted to indonesian nationalism). this arcepelego spanning concept of nationality, for a time, competed with the island based independence movements, that promoted natavist, blood and land, concept of nationality. the more familiar inherited nationality. in the 1920-30s these natavist independence movements disbanded and merged with the arcepelego spanning nationality, both were united in their opposition to dutch colonial rule. in 1945, shortly after japanese occupation ended, indonesian nationalists declared independence, resulting in a conflict between indonesian nationalists, the dutch colonial power (and allied countries) and well as an internal struggle, often against communists (a bit of a mess). over 100,000 people were killed.

this is an intensely problematic thread in so many ways. nobody is discussing facts, only feelings and assumptions. childbirth is one of the most dangerous things a woman can do, anywhere in the world. <url> when it comes to birth rates, there are multiple factors: - cultural expectations around marriage birth control number of children - age at marriage conception - availability of contraceptives etc when it comes to maternal infant mortality rates, there are also many factors. - antenatal care - skilled birth attendence - emergency obstetric care - postpartum care - access to contraception - nutritional support etc besides the risk of harm due to violence, conflicts promote social instability, weaken health systems, undermine support networks, and hamper access to essential services and necessities. in 2022 (the last year with available data, there were 57 442 live births in gaza. gaza west bank combined (because that is how the data is reported) have the 1 highest birth rate in the middle east. very, very few studies are done on reproductive outcomes in the midst of conflict. here is one that was done between october and november 2024, in gaza. <url> a very brief synopsis - honestly, go read the study. - 517 women gave birth during the study in the 3 hospitals included. - 17 were excluded from the study for various reasons - women were between 16-46, median age 28 - more than half had a normal bmi (measure of body weight) - the majority had given birth previously - approximately 1 3 had complications in pregnancy, like anemia, hypertension or uti - 65% had no complications - 90% were delivered on time (median 39 weeks gestational age) and at a normal birth weight - 10% of neonates were delivered at a low birth weight - all newborns survived birth, - 5% required resuscitation - 8.5% were admitted to the nicu in general, the women's most significant concerns in pregnancy were around labour and delivery (43%). some (20%) reported their most significant concern being personal safety. a majority reported food supply diversity as being inadequate, however only 1% reported securing food as their most significant concern. here is a study measuring food deliveries into gaza that overlaps with the maternal-infant outcomes study: <url> i don't know what sources you have been reading and i don't know what they are reporting. but whatever you see or read, go check the data.

there are things called positive rights and negative rights. a positive right is a right that requires a specific action to uphold it while a negative right is a right that requires inaction to uphold it. for example, a right to housing is a positive right and it means someone will have to build houses so that everyone can have that right. a negative right is something like freedom of speech where the government is not permitted to infringe on people‚Äôs ability to speak. the problem with positive rights compared to negative rights is that they have to come from somewhere and there aren‚Äôt always enough resources or manpower to provide everything for everyone. occasionally that means taking resources from people by force in order to give it to others. the us (and israel to an extent) think problems such as food should be solved via charity and fundraising rather than by force.

>einstein was a close associate of david ben gurion. no he wasn‚Äôt. einstein was a close associate of arnold sommerfeld or paul ehrenfest or oskar morgenstern (for example). it is hardly fair to describe the relationship with ben gurion with the same words given the difference in the exchange between einstein and the others i mentioned. einstein was even at times critical (to third parties like max born) about people in power in israel in the thirties to early fifties, such as those he associated more with ‚Äòpolitical zionism‚Äô rather than einstein‚Äôs self-professed ‚Äòspiritual zionism‚Äô. einstein‚Äôs connection with judaism was tinged by this very distinction, the one we try to draw today! he loved his people and their customs and traditions, and wanted to secure their safety. but he was also painfully aware of what the homogeneity (a bit reductive, but just for instance) of a society can be used for in the wrong hands (fascism).

genocide is a legal term. the original proposal by the polish jewish scholar raphael lemkin was watered down by many countries in the un for fear of being persecuted for their own actions. so you can see how different folks may use different definitions to pass judgment. the genocide convention defines genocide as: ... any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, as such: (a) killing members of the group; (b) causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group; (c) deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part; (d) imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group; (e) forcibly transferring children of the group to another group. i'll encourage you to read up on genocide to understand the context.
